description: We train neural networks with depth of over 150 layers for classification, detection, and segmentation. We propose a “deep residual learning” framework [a] that eases the optimization and convergence of extremely deep networks. Our “deep residual nets” enjoy accuracy gains when the networks are substantially deeper than those used previously. Such accuracy gains are not witnessed for many common networks when going deeper. Our instance semantic system is based on our work in [b]. We build a Multi-task Network Cascade for proposing regions, regressing masks, and categorizing instances. We develop an end-to-end algorithm for training this causal, cascaded system. In particular, we propose an “RoI warping” layer that is differentiable with respect to the region coordinates, so the entire backpropagation can be performed in a theoretically valid way. Our object detection system is based on the “Faster R-CNN” system in our NIPS paper [c]. The region proposal network (RPN) in Faster R-CNN effectively learns the proposals on the COCO dataset, and the result in this submission is obtained by using only 300 proposals per image for a single model. The object detection network is built based on the observations in [d]. Both object detection and instance segmentation systems benefit greatly from the extremely deep residual networks. On the COCO detection dataset, Faster R-CNN with a 101-layer residual net shows 30% relative improvement over the counterpart Faster R-CNN with VGG-16. The training set for the classification network is the 1000-class ImageNet training set. The training set for the detection task is the MS COCO trainval set with box-level annotations. The training set for the segmentation task is the MS COCO trainval set with mask-level annotations. [a] “Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition”, Kaiming He, Xiangyu Zhang, Shaoqing Ren, Jian Sun. Tech Report 2015. [b] “Instance-aware semantic segmentation via multi-task network cascades”, Jifeng Dai, Kaiming He, Jian Sun. Tech Report 2015. [c] “Faster R-CNN: Towards Real-Time Object Detection with Region Proposal Networks”, Shaoqing Ren, Kaiming He, Ross Girshick, Jian Sun. NIPS 2015. [d] “Object Detection Networks on Convolutional Feature Maps”, Shaoqing Ren, Kaiming He, Ross Girshick, Xiangyu Zhang, Jian Sun. arXiv 2015.

team.members: Kaiming He, Shaoqing Ren, Jifeng Dai, Xiangyu Zhang, Jian Sun
team.name: MSRA

description: We use CNN to segment and detect objects. We use a patch merging step to generate final results.

team.members: Shu Liu, Xiaojuan Qi

description: Our approach is built on DeepMask proposals fed into the Fast R-CNN pipeline. The DeepMask proposals have been substantially improved to encourage proposal diversity and mask quality. We also augmented our CNN classifier with a novel foveal structure, skip-connections, an improved cost function that encourages better localization, and a few additional modifications. Finally we utilize aggressive ensembling (model and inference) to further improve performance.

team.members: Sergey Zagoruyko*, Tsung-Yi Lin*, Pedro O. Pinheiro*, Adam Lerer, Sam Gross, Soumith Chintala, Piotr Dollár (*equal contribution)
team.name: FAIRCNN

description: Our entry is based on "Fully Convolutional Instance-aware Semantic Segmentation[a]". It is a fully convolutional end-to-end solution for instance aware semantic segmentation. The proposed method is much faster and more accurate than the previous challenge winning Multi-task Network Cascade method. We utilize an ensemble of ResNet models, which are pre-trained on ImageNet, and finetuned on COCO trainval. Code would be released at https://github.com/daijifeng001/TA-FCN. [a] “Fully Convolutional Instance-aware Semantic Segmentation”, Yi Li*, Haozhi Qi*, Jifeng Dai, Xiangyang Ji, Yichen Wei (*equal contribution). https://arxiv.org/abs/1611.07709, arXiv 2016.

team.members: Jifeng Dai*, Haozhi Qi*, Yi Li* (* Equal contribution)
team.name: MSRA

description: Instance segmentation with multi-level deep features and Dense CRF with ROI pooling over candidate object detection regions.

team.members: Peng Wang, Sergio Guadarrama, Kevin Murphy
team.name: G-RMI

team.members: *Kaiming He, *Ross Girshick, Ilija Radosavovic, Georgia Gkioxari, Piotr Dollár (* denotes equal first authorship); Facebook AI Research
team.name: FAIR Mask R-CNN

description: Our entry is built upon the following papers developed at FAIR: (i) Mask R-CNN [1], for bbox and mask prediction; (ii) Feature Pyramid Networks (FPN) [2], and (iii) ResNeXt [3] 152-32x8d pre-trained on ImageNet-5k as in [3], as the backbone. No data labeled with boxes or masks, beyond what is provided in COCO, are used in our entry. No data other than ImageNet-5k were used for network pre-training. Main results on test-dev include: (i) Single-model without test-time augmentation: 45.5 bbox AP and 40.8 mask AP, which runs at 3 FPS on an NVIDIA P100 GPU while predicting both boxes and masks (ii) Single-model with test-time augmentation (multi-scale testing and horizontal image flipping): 47.9 bbox AP and 42.6 mask AP (iii) Ensembling of Mask R-CNN models for the competition: 49.5 bbox AP and 43.5 mask AP (3 models); 50.3 bbox AP and 43.8 mask AP (30 models). We will release our codebase ("Detectron") which includes Mask R-CNN, FPN, and ResNeXt. [1] https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.06870 [2] https://arxiv.org/abs/1612.03144 [3] https://arxiv.org/abs/1611.05431

team.members: Ruixuan Luo*, Borui Jiang*, Tete Xiao*, Chao Peng*, Yuning Jiang, Zeming Li, Xiangyu Zhang, Gang Yu, Jian Sun (* indicates equal contribution); Megvii Research
team.name: Megvii (Face++)

description: We first trained a modified Mask-RCNN[1] with context modules. Then, we chopped the detection branch and inserted four more layers into mask branch. The new mask branch was randomly initialized thereafter and the whole network was fine-tuned with sophisticated regression target of mask branch. For both training stages, we used very large batch size via synchronized parallel training (up to 40 GPUs) on Megvii (Face++)’s large-scale deep learning framework, MegBrain. We did not use the MSCOCO provided unlabeled images or other training data. At test time multi-scale and horizontal flip were applied. The single model achieved 45.0 mAP on minival set. The final result was obtained by the ensemble of two networks. [1] Kaiming He, Georgia Gkioxari, Piotr Dollar, Ross Girshick. Mask RCNN. ICCV 2017.
A single model doing simultaneous detection and segmentation based on VGGNet.
rfcn+mask; dataset: coco 2014 2017 train+val, pre-trained resnet model.

team.members: Haozhi Qi, Zheng Zhang, Bin Xiao, Han Hu, Bowen Cheng, Yichen Wei, Jifeng Dai (Microsoft Research Asia)
team.name: MSRA

description: The entry is based on Deformable ConvNets [1] and Xception network [2]. The deformable convolution and deformable RoI pooling modules introduced in [1] can effectively enhance the transformation modeling capacity of ConvNets. The new modules can readily replace their plain counterparts in existing ConvNets and can be easily trained end-to-end by standard back-propagation, giving rise to Deformable ConvNets. On top of a strong baseline (Xception + FPN [3] + SoftNMS [4]), Deformable ConvNets boost the mAP by a clear margin (~3%). In the entry, ImageNet classification is the only external data utilized for network pretraining. The single model performance of Deformable ConvNets is 48.5% (with Xception + FPN + SoftNMS). The final entry utilize an ensemble of 6 models. [1] Jifeng Dai, Haozhi Qi, Yuwen Xiong, Yi Li, Guodong Zhang, Han Hu, Yichen Wei. "Deformable Convolutional Networks". In ICCV 2017. [2] François Chollet. “Xception: Deep Learning with Depthwise Separable Convolutions”. In CVPR 2017. [3] Tsung-Yi Lin, Piotr Dollár, Ross Girshick, Kaiming He, Bharath Hariharan, Serge Belongie. "Feature Pyramid Networks for Object Detection". In CVPR 2017. [4] Navaneeth Bodla, Bharat Singh, Rama Chellappa, Larry S. Davis. “Soft-NMS -- Improving Object Detection With One Line of Code”. In ICCV 2017. URL: https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.06211 https://github.com/msracver/Deformable-ConvNets

team.members: Peng Xu, Institute of Computer Science & Technology, Peking University, Beijing, China; Gu Wang, Department of Automation, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Jialin Wu, Department of Automation, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Qian Wang, Department of Automation, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
team.name: Tsinghua-fcis

description: Our team has made three submissions to the test-challenge2017 evaluation server for segmentation mask detection. All the training data is from COCO 2017. The first submission is generated by a fully convolutional instance-aware semantic segmentation network (FCIS) [1]. The average precision of FCIS is 29% on COCO test-dev set, and the inference time is 0.1s per image on a TITAN Xp. The second and third submissions are generated by a deformable convolutional instance-aware semantic segmentation network (DCIS). The architecture of DCIS is similar to the FCIS, while some convolution layers are replaced by deformable convolution layers [2]. As the convolution layer is a special case of the deformable convolution layer, DCIS has all advantages of FCIS. With deformable convolution layers, the DCIS is more effective to learn deep features for the segmentation task. The second and third submissions are evaluated on different training epoch of a DCIS model. The average precisions of the second and third submissions are 27.8% and 28.0% on COCO test-dev set. The inference time of DCIS is 0.22s per image on a TITAN Xp. [1] Yi Li, Haozhi Qi, Jifeng Dai, Xiangyang Ji and Yichen Wei. "Fully Convolutional Instance-aware Semantic Segmentation," CVPR, 2017 [2] Jifeng Dai, Haozhi Qi, Yuwen Xiong, Yi Li, Guodong Zhang, Han Hu, Yichen Wei. "Deformable Convolutional Networks," arxiv: 1703.06211, 2017.

team.members: Jaehyup Jeong*(Inha Univ.), Hunjun Yang*(Inha Univ.), Seungjae Lee(ETRI), Weongeun Oh(ETRI), Bowon Lee(Inha Univ.) (*Equal contribution)
team.name: INET

description: We trained variants of FCIS [1] with deformable methods in [2]. For ensembles, we used ResNets [3] and ResNeXt [4] as base networks and performed multi-scale testing. The ensembles consist of three models with the single model performance of 32.2%. No external data was used for the training. The inference time is 0.252 seconds/image with 4 Titan Xp GPUs. [1] "Fully Convolutional Instance-Aware Semantic Segmentation", Yi Li, Haozhi Qi, Jifeng Dai, Xiangyang Ji and Yichen Wei, CVPR 2017  [2] "Deformable Convolutional Networks", Jifeng Dai, Haozhi Qi, Yuwen Xiong, Yi Li, Guodong Zhang, Han Hu, Yichen Wei, arXiv preprint arXiv:1703.06211, 2017 [3] "Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition", Kaiming He and Xiangyu Zhang and Shaoqing Ren and Jian Sun, arXiv preprint arXiv:1512.03385, 2015 [4] "Aggregated Residual Transformations for Deep Neural Networks", Saining Xie and Ross Girshick and Piotr Dollar and Zhuowen Tu and Kaiming He, arXiv preprint arXiv:1611.05431, 2016

team.members: Shu Liu [a], Lu Qi [a], Haifang Qin [b], Jianping Shi [b], Jiaya Jia [a]; [a] The Chinese University of Hong Kong, [b] Sensetime
team.name: UCenter

description: We develop a novel region-based object detection and instance segmentation approach by boosting information flow from across layers, iterative pyramid and global context information. We use a feature pyramid Mask RCNN as our backbone [1, 2]. Our contributions are listed as follows. 1) Instead of assigning object proposals to different levels by a heuristic metric, we allow each proposal adaptively to pick useful information from all levels, leading to improved information flow from across layers. 2) We augment another path from lower layers to top layers based on the observation that larger objects could surprisingly benefit more from lower layer features, resulting in improved information flow from iterative pyramid. 3) We augment the FCN-like mask prediction branch with tiny fully-connected layers, improving information flow from global context information when predicting pixel-wise mask. As a result, masks with higher quality are produced. Our models are pre-trained on ImageNet and fine-tuned on COCO trainval subset with mask annotations. We directly take the tighten bounding boxes around each mask prediction as our object detection results. Our best single model performance is 44 in terms of instance segmentation and 47.8 in terms of object detection on test-dev subset. We find that the performances based on Resnext-101 (64*4d), SE-ResNext-101 (32*4d), Resnet-269 and SENet are just comparable. We hypothesis the reason is that the limited GPU memory makes the larger models can only be trained on smaller image input which limits their capability. For ensemble, we used 3 Resnext-101 (64*4d), 2 Se-ResNext-101 (32*4d), 1 Resnet-269 and 1 SENet. With network ensemble, we achieve 46.7 in terms of instance segmentation and 51 in terms of object detection on test-dev subset. [1] T. Lin, P. Dollár, R. B. Girshick, K. He, B. Hariharan, and S. J. Belongie. Feature pyramid networks for object detection. CVPR 2017. [2] K. He, G. Gkioxari, P. Dolla ́r and R. B. Girshick. Mask R-CNN. ICCV 2017.

team.name: 1 model from scratch
team.members: Kaiming He, Ross Girshick, Piotr Dollár. FAIR

description: Our submission is a single-model entry trained from random initialization ("from scratch"), without using any pre-training or external data. This is made possible by Group Normalization (GN) [Wu & He, 2018]. Our model trained from random initialization has accuracy of 51.3 bbox AP and 43.6 mask AP on the test-dev set. Our model is Mask R-CNN with a ResNeXt-152-FPN backbone and GN. Training-time and test-time data augmentation is used. Implementation is from the publicly available code of Detectron, with the only improvement of adding Cascade R-CNN [Cai & Vasconcelos, 2018].

team.name: DVU
team.members: Taehoon Kim, Oleksandr Baiev, Kyeyoung Jeong, Jaehwan Kim, Jimin Park, Hyeonggon Kim, Jangho Yoon, Yoonmee Lee.

description: Our model is based on Deformable ConvNets [1], Mask RCNN [2], and Cascade RCNN [3]. The deformable convolution module introduced in [1] can effectively enhance the transformation modeling capacity of ConvNets, and the three stage cascade prediction heads in [3] can refine the quality of bboxes. Mask head is trained from last stage prediction head. This baseline is ResNeXt-152. [1] "Deformable Convolutional Networks", https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.06211. [2] "Mask R-CNN", https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.06870. [3]"Cascade RCNN", https://arxiv.org/abs/1712.00726. Additional information: 1) No external data. 2) Single model. 3) inference time: 278ms on P40 GPU

team.name: VISION DU
team.members: Yuan Gao; Xingyuan Bu; Yang Hu; Yi Fu; Wujing Zhan; Ti Bai; Hui Shen; Xubin Li; Shilei Wen.

description: We trained a Mask-RCNN[1] in COCO2017 training set with ImageNet 1000 pretrain. We used FPN[2], Group Normalize[3], Path Aggregation Network[4] Deformable Roi align[5], and an extra ASPP[6] branch to learning better feature for instance segmentation. In COCO 2017 test-dev, the best single model we trained achieves 45.3% mAP in terms of Instance Segmentation and 51.7% mAP in terms of Object Detection. Multi scale input and image flip was used in both train and test time. The final result was the ensemble of three models included ResNeXt 152, SeNeXt-154. [1] He, K., et al. (2017). "Mask r-cnn." CVPR. [2] Lin, T.-Y., et al. (2017). Feature pyramid networks for object detection. CVPR. [3] Wu, Y. and K. He (2018). "Group Normalization." arXiv:1803.08494. [4] Liu, S., et al. (2018). "Path Aggregation Network for Instance Segmentation." arXiv preprint arXiv:1803.01534. [5] Dai, J., et al. (2017). "Deformable convolutional networks." CoRR, abs/1703.06211 1: 3. [6] Chen, L. C., et al. (2018). "Encoder-decoder with atrous separable convolution for semantic image segmentation." arXiv preprint arXiv:1802.02611.

team.name: X-Man
team.members: Jianshu Li; Jian Zhao; Huaxin Xiao; Yunpeng Chen; Jian Dong; Jiashi Feng; Shuicheng Yan

description: Enhancement of MaskRCNN with various components, such as squeeze and excitation networks, non-local networks, path aggregation networks, deformable convolutional networks, dual path networks, etc. No external data was used and the final result is obtained from an ensemble of 8 models.

team.name: Megvii (Face++)
team.members: Zeming Li, Yueqing Zhuang, Xiangyu Zhang, Gang Yu, Jian Sun. Megvii (Face++)

description: We adopt a two-pass pipeline for instance segmentation. In the first pass, we use MegDet [1] system to obtain object detection results. The MegDet detector employs the recent ShuffleNet v2 [2] as the backbone network. An ensemble of 4 detectors achieves 55.4 mmAP (box) on the validation set. All models are trained from the combination of COCO and an external dataset, which will be released later this year. In the second pass, we train a tailored Mask R-CNN network to generate the segmentation masks. We integrate the regression and segmentation tasks in a shared branch, both of which are localization sensitive. We leave the classification task in another branch. In the final inference stage, the segmentation result is obtained by replacing the ROIs generated by the first pass of object detection. We only use a single instance segmentation model for the final submission. It achieves 48.8 mAP on the test-dev. The model is trained on 32 Tesla V100 GPU cards. [1] MegDet: A Large Mini-Batch Object Detector, Chao Peng, Tete Xiao, Zeming Li, Yuning Jiang, Xiangyu Zhang, Kai Jia, Gang Yu, Jian Sun, CVPR 2018. [2] ShuffleNet V2: Practical Guidelines for Efficient CNN Architecture Design, Ningning Ma, Xiangyu Zhang, Hai-Tao Zheng, Jian Sun, ECCV 2018

team.name: MMDet
team.members: Kai Chen[1], Jiangmiao Pang[2,3], Jiaqi Wang[1], Yu Xiong[1], Xiaoxiao Li[1], Shuyang Sun[4], Wansen Feng[2], Ziwei Liu[1], Jianping Shi[2], Wanli Ouyang[4], Chen Change Loy[1,5], Dahua Lin[1]. [1] The Chinese University of Hong Kong. [2] SenseTime Research. [3] Zhejiang University. [4] University of Sydney. [5] Nanyang Technological University.

description: We develop a novel framework in this contest, which is distinguished from previous ones in three aspects: a new hybrid cascade architecture, a more intelligent anchoring scheme, and a new backbone network called FishNet. (1) We organize the entire pipeline with a hybrid cascade architecture, where branches for different tasks, including bounding box regression, mask prediction, and semantic segmentation, are organized in an interleaved way. This new architecture improves the information flow such that knowledges from different modules can be exchanged more effectively. (2) We develop a feature guided anchoring scheme instead of using dense and uniform anchors. This scheme predicts sparse anchors of arbitrary shapes, resulting in a significant performing gain of the RPN  (AR raised by around 10%). (3) We incorporate a new backbone called FishNet in our ensemble, which can preserve and refine features of the same resolution from varying depths (accepted to NIPS 2018). The experiment settings are described as follows: we use COCO train2017 with bbox, mask and stuff annotations for training. We train five models with different backbone structures: SE-ResNeXt-154 (64*4d), ResNeXt-101 (64*4d), ResNeXt-101 (32*8d), DPN-107, and FishNet. The predictions from these networks are combined at the end. Here are some results on test-dev: (1) single model (single scale testing): 45.3 mask AP, (2) single model (multi-scale testing with flip): 47.4 mask AP, (3) ensemble of 5 models: 49.0 mask AP. We also develop *mm-detection*, a comprehensive and high performance object detection package based on PyTorch. During the COCO workshop, we are going to release this package, in order to promote the research in this area. References: [1] T. Lin, P. Dollár, R. B. Girshick, K. He, B. Hariharan, and S. J. Belongie. Feature pyramid networks for object detection. CVPR 2017. [2] K. He, G. Gkioxari, P. Dollár and R. B. Girshick. Mask R-CNN. ICCV 2017. [3] Z. Cai, N. Vasconcelos. Cascade R-CNN: Delving into High Quality Object Detection. CVPR 2018.

team.name: DL-61
team.members: Zhe Chen, Dacheng Tao

description: In this challenge, we attempt to tackle the instance segmentation task with Mask RCNN based on a small batch size, i.e. 4. Since the small batch size would cause more unstable training and worse performance, we adopt several novel and effective techniques. First, we introduce group normalization [1] to stabilize the representation of CNN and use context refinement [2] to improve the accuracy of detected bounding boxes. Second, we try to alter the training statistics for different categories of objects because we find that the objects with fewer samples in the dataset generally have much worse performance. Since the small batch size cannot overcome this problem effectively, we introduce class re-sampling and class re-weighing strategies so that objects with fewer samples can also be trained adequately. The class re-sampling, which is similar to label smoothing, will sample more for the categories that have fewer objects in the dataset. The class re-weighing will then assign the objects that have a worse performance with higher weights in the loss function during training. Moreover, we introduce multi-scale training and crop training to boost robustness and accuracy. We also perform class-wise ensemble to augment the final performance. All our experiments are based on 4-GPU servers. Our single best model achieves 42.8 on test-dev dataset. No external data is used in our experiments. 10 Mask R-CNN models are used for the final ensemble which achieves 44.7 on test-dev. Reference: [1] Wu, Yuxin, and Kaiming He. "Group Normalization", ECCV'18. [2] Zhe Chen, Shaoli Huang, and Dacheng Tao. "Context Refinement for Object Detection", ECCV'18.

team.name: mmap-seg
team.members: Qi Zheng, Min Yang, Chenyang Li, Peng Huang, Chao Liang, Jun Chen (National Engineering Research Center for Multimedia Software, School of Computer Science and Engineering, Wuhan University).

description: Our method is based on Mask-rcnn[1]. And we combine the canny edge detected results with Mask-rcnn in the post-processing phase to refined the segmentation results. It cost about one week to train the model on single Titan XP GPU. Besides, only the COCO data (no external data) is used for training our method. [1] He K, Gkioxari G, Dollar P, et al. Mask R-CNN[J]. IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis & Machine Intelligence, 2017, PP(99):1-1.

team.name: INET
team.members: Hunjun Yang(Inha Univ.), Seungjae Lee(ETRI), Weongeun Oh(ETRI), Bowon Lee(Inha Univ.)

description: We trained variants of Mask R-CNN[1] with deformable convolution[2] and SE block[3] in  ResNets[4] and ResNeXt[5] as base networks. The best single model performance with test augmentation is 0.383 on test-dev dataset. The ensembles consist of 5 different trained models and accuracy is 0.404 on test-dev dataset. No external data was used for the training. The inference time is 0.172 seconds/image with Titan Xp GPU in the best single model with test augmentation. [1] "Mask R-CNN", Kaiming He, Georgia Gkioxari, Piotr Dollar, Ross Girshick, arXiv:1703.06870, 2017. [2] "Deformable Convolutional Networks", Jifeng Dai, Haozhi Qi, Yuwen Xiong, Yi Li, Guodong Zhang, Han Hu, Yichen Wei, arXiv:1703.06211, 2017. [3] "Squeeze-and-Excitation Networks", Jie Hu, Li Shen, Gang Sun, arXiv:1709.01507, 2017. [4] "Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition", Kaiming He and Xiangyu Zhang and Shaoqing Ren and Jian Sun, arXiv preprint arXiv:1512.03385, 2015. [5] "Aggregated Residual Transformations for Deep Neural Networks", Saining Xie and Ross Girshick and Piotr Dollar and Zhuowen Tu and Kaiming He, arXiv preprint arXiv:1611.05431, 2016.

team.name: swjtu-mmlab
team.members: Deng-Ke Wu, Jun-Yan He, Xiao Wu, Fan Xu, Chen-Yang Shi (Southwest Jiaotong University).

description: This entry is based on Mask R-CNN[1] and FPN(Feature Pyramid Networks)[2] with ResNeXt [3] 152-32x8d pre-trained on ImageNet-5k as backbone. We adopted adaptive pooling[4] in RoI pooling for Fast R-CNN[5] head and deformable convolutions[6] in backbone. Our best single model was trained end-to-end on coco_train_2017, achieving mAP of 41.6% for instance segmentation task and 48.5% for object detection task on test-dev, with multi-scale training, multi-scale testing, soft-nms[7] and bbox voting. This model was trained on 4 Titan Xp GPUs for 7~8 days. The final entry uses a two-model ensemble. One is released by FAIR as ResNeXt-152-32x8d [8] fine-tuned on an equivalence to coco_train_2017, the other one is our best single model. We extract 3000 proposals for every image, then use these two models to predict every proposal for position regression and score without any post-processing. Then, averaging is applied along the model direction, followed by bbox voting and soft-nms[7] with proper threshold. The bbox prediction ensemble is input to our best single model, obtaining the final instance segmentation result of 42.4%. No extra data used. The code to train our model is modified from "Detectron" [6]. [1] Kaiming He, Georgia Gkioxari, Piotr Dollar, Ross Girshick. "Mask RCNN". In ICCV 2017. [2] Tsung-Yi Lin, Piotr Dollár, Ross Girshick, Kaiming He, Bharath Hariharan, Serge Belongie. "Feature Pyramid Networks for Object Detection". In CVPR 2017.  [3] Saining Xie, Ross Girshick, Piotr Dollár, Zhuowen Tu, Kaiming He. "Aggregated Residual Transformations for Deep Neural Networks". In CVPR 2017. [4] Shu Liu, Lu Qi, Haifang Qin, Jianping Shi, Jiaya Jia. "Path Aggregation Network for Instance Segmentation". In CVPR 2018. [5] Ross Girshick. "Fast R-CNN". In ICCV 2015. [6] Jifeng Dai, Haozhi Qi, Yuwen Xiong, Yi Li, Guodong Zhang, Han Hu, Yichen Wei. "Deformable Convolutional Networks". In ICCV 2017. [7] Navaneeth Bodla, Bharat Singh, Rama Chellappa, Larry S. Davis. “Soft-NMS -- Improving Object Detection With One Line of Code”. In ICCV 2017. [8] https://github.com/facebookresearch/Detectron

team.name: DetLab
team.members: Boyuan Sun, Hang Zhang (Yi+ AILab)

description: It is a single model using MaskRCNN architecture based on ResNeXt152 backbone pre-trained on ImageNet, then post-process detection results using SoftNMS. We train our model on COCO train2017 and obtained mAP: 41.8% on COCO test-dev (Det mAP: 48.8%).

team.name: FirstShot
team.members: Chaoxu Guo*, Zhaojin Huang*, Yudong Wu, Zhengkai Jiang, Xinze Chen, Yun Ye, Lichao Huang, Qian Zhang, Guan Huang (* indicates equal contribution)

description: We develop a region-based object detection and instance segmentation approach, which follows Mask-RCNN[1]. Feature pyramid network[2] is used as our backbone for multi-scale feature extraction. And we use Cascade-RCNN[3] as our box head, which iteratively regresses, refines the box location and predicts the object class. For mask head, we propose a new module called Cascade-Mask, which exploits the rois of different stage from box head to iteratively refine the mask results and improve the mask result by 1.3% on minival set. Our single model based on senet154 achieved 46.5% mAP in terms of Instance Segmentation on test-dev and 52.5 mAP in terms of object detection. The final result is obtained by the ensemble of 4 models including 3 senet154 and 1 resnext 152. With network ensemble we achieved 47.0 mAP in terms of Instance Segmentatiog and 53.3 mAP in terms of object detection on test-dev. No external data was used for all our entries. [1]K. He, G. Gkioxari, P. Dolla ́r and R. B. Girshick. Mask R-CNN. ICCV 2017. [2]T. Lin, P. Dolla ́r, R. B. Girshick, K. He, B. Hariharan, and S. J. Belongie. Feature pyramid networks for object detection. CVPR 2017. [3]Cai, Z., Vasconcelos, N.: Cascade r-cnn: Delving into high quality object detection. CVPR2018.

team.name: dimage
team.members: Chengxiang Yin, Lin Wu, Wanxin Tian, Xiehe Huang, Luyan Chen, Yuan Zhao, Ziyuan Lin (AI Labs, Didi Chuxing).

description: We change the architecture of feature extractor for the purpose of performance improvement of objects with different sizes (e.g. small objects). Besides the bottom-up path augmentation architecture designed by PANet, which leads to the redundancy of high-level semantic information and can improve the performance of large objects, we propose two innovative architectures based on FPN, which are focused on the small objects and medium objects. Then we ensemble the segmentation results of the above 3 feature extractor architectures to get our final result for submission. Only COCO Dataset was used in this competition. The single model performance (AP) can reach 42.1 on Test-dev, and 11 models were ensembled to get our best result on Test-dev with AP equals 43.1.
